Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an imaging Raman spectrometer for research and training
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Major Research Instrumentation Program and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Massimo Bertino from Virginia Commonwealth University and colleagues Dexian Ye, Joseph Reiner, Everett Carpenter and Collen Taylor (the latter from Virginia State University) will acquire a scanning confocal Raman microscope. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) surface-enhanced Raman scattering on noble metal coated metal nanotips; (b) detection of NO in blood and tissue; (c) nanopore-facilitated loading of nanosharps; (d) functionally-graded silica films and their characterization on multiple length scales; and (e) aerogel cross-linking.

Raman spectroscopy measures the vibrational frequencies of molecules in a sample which are characteristic of the chemical content, composition and structure of the material. A Raman microscope scans across a sample to provide a spatial image of the chemical composition in response to the laser probe. This widely used technique, employing lasers to probe the material, is non-destructive. This instrument will strengthen graduate and undergraduate education as students use this instrument in their research projects and in laboratory courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on acquisition of a mapping Raman microscope to be used for research and student training. The instrument was purchased and installed in a dedicated room at the Nanocharacterization Core Facility (NCC). Since installation, it has been operating continuously with the exception of a brief (1 month) interval in the summer of 2016, where minor optics alignment issues required a site visit from a technician. To help collaboarative work, we installed software that allows to control the instrument from a remote location. This  allows students and researchers to operate the instrument at night and also to carry out remote analysis of their data. The instrument is the only vibrational characterization instrument available at the NCC. It  has become quite popular and its usage is currently on par with those of other instruments at the NCC. The instrument is currently being used by several research groups in the College of Humanities and Sciences (Chemistry, Physics, Biology, Forensic Sciences), the School of Engineering (Biomedical, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering), and by the School of Medicine (Department of Pharmacology).  Thanks to the possibility of remote access, we could  also establish collaborations with research groups in Germany and with our satellite campus in Qatar.    To date, we have trained about 25 students on this instrument, 12 of which undergraduates. About 10 manuscripts have been published which made use of the instrument.
